needs.description: As of February 2026, Khartoum remains under active conflict with hospitals operating at 15-20% capacity. Al-Shaab Teaching Hospital, the largest in the city, has been out of service since mid-2023. WHO reports over 70% of health facilities in Khartoum state are non-functional, and maternal mortality has risen to 850 per 100,000 live births, nearly triple pre-war levels.

Only 30% of Khartoum's water treatment plants are operational, forcing residents to rely on untreated water sources. Cholera cases have surged to 8,500 since January 2025, with 180 deaths reported. Sewage systems in Omdurman and Bahri districts are completely non-functional.

Over 2.5 million people remain internally displaced within Khartoum state, with 60% living in overcrowded collective shelters lacking basic services. Spontaneous settlements in East Nile and Jabal Awliya localities have tripled since December 2024.

needs.description: El Fasher remains under siege with active hostilities between SAF and RSF forces. UN reports indicate 800,000 civilians trapped with no safe exit routes. Artillery shelling has damaged 40% of residential buildings in the city center, and markets have been non-operational since October 2024.

IPC analysis shows El Fasher is in Phase 5 (Catastrophe) with 25% of the population experiencing extreme food consumption gaps. Food prices have increased by 450% since 2023, and the main market has been closed for 14 months. Malnutrition rates among children under 5 have reached 22%.

Only two hospitals remain partially functional in El Fasher, serving a population of 800,000. WHO reports 15,000 trauma cases untreated due to lack of surgical capacity. Maternal deaths have increased by 400% compared to pre-conflict levels.

needs.description: Nyala hosts over 450,000 newly displaced people who arrived between October 2023 and February 2025, overwhelming existing infrastructure. Spontaneous camps have emerged around Kass locality, with families living in makeshift shelters without adequate sanitation.

IPC Phase 4 (Emergency) conditions affect 65% of South Darfur state, with Nyala as the main urban center. Food insecurity has driven acute malnutrition rates to 18.5% among children under 5, exceeding WHO emergency thresholds.

Protection clusters report 1,200+ cases of gender-based violence in Nyala in the past six months, with actual numbers estimated to be 3-4 times higher due to underreporting. Child protection cases have doubled since 2023, with 3,500 unaccompanied minors documented.

needs.description: Port Sudan has received over 850,000 displaced people since April 2023, straining urban services. The city's population has effectively doubled, with 60% of arrivals living in host communities rather than formal camps, creating tensions over resources.

Port Sudan's main port, handling 70% of humanitarian cargo, operates at 60% capacity due to damaged cranes and security constraints. Fuel shortages have limited electricity generation to 4 hours daily in most neighborhoods.

Port Sudan's hospitals are operating at 85% capacity with 12,000 monthly consultations. However, medicine stocks are at 30% of required levels, particularly affecting chronic disease patients. Dengue fever cases have reached 2,400 since January 2025.

needs.description: Geneina experienced complete destruction in 2023-2024 with 87% of buildings damaged or destroyed. The city remains largely abandoned with only 15% of the pre-conflict population of 300,000 remaining. Active hostilities continue in surrounding areas.

West Darfur remains under IPC Phase 5 (Catastrophe) conditions with 35% of the population in El Geneina locality experiencing extreme food consumption gaps. Markets have been non-functional for 18 months, and food aid delivery has been blocked by ongoing insecurity.

Protection clusters document 2,800+ incidents of violence against civilians in West Darfur since January 2024, including 480 killings. Ethnic targeting has created protection concerns for specific communities attempting to return.

needs.description: Gedaref state, traditionally Sudan's breadbasket, faces severe production shortfalls with only 40% of agricultural land cultivated in 2024-2025 season. IPC analysis shows 60% of Gedaref's 1.8 million population in Phase 3+ food insecurity.

Gedaref hosts 320,000 displaced people, primarily from Blue Nile and Sennar states. Most are living with host communities, straining local resources. Spontaneous settlements lack basic services, with only 15% having access to functioning latrines.
Only 35% of Gedaref's water points are functional due to lack of maintenance and fuel shortages. Open defecation has increased by 200% in displacement-hosting areas, raising disease outbreak risks.
